Using knitractive with Bash

Jeroen Janssens

2021-11-16

Source: vignettes/examples/bash.Rmd
bash.Rmd

View the corresponding bash.Rmd file to learn more about how this page was generated.

Set a variable

$ NAME=$(whoami)

Spread a pipeline over multiple lines

$ seq 100 |
> grep 3 |
> wc -l
19

Retrieve a value

$ cowsay "I am g${NAME}"
 ____________
< I am groot >
 ------------
        \   ^__^
         \  (oo)\_______
            (__)\       )\/\
                ||----w |
                ||     ||

Command substitution

$ echo "CRAN has $(
>   curl -sL cran.r-project.org/web/packages/available_packages_by_date.html |
>   grep "index.html" |
>   wc -l
> ) packages"
CRAN has 18424 packages

Take a screenshot of top 

$ top

After two seconds we see the following screen:

top - 20:07:12 up 2 days, 12:50,  0 users,  load average: 0.29, 0.09, 0.02      
Tasks:   2 total,   1 running,   1 sleeping,   0 stopped,   0 zombie            
%Cpu(s):  0.0 us,  1.6 sy,  0.0 ni, 98.4 id,  0.0 wa,  0.0 hi,  0.0 si,  0.0 st 
MiB Mem :   3933.6 total,   1373.2 free,    941.5 used,   1618.9 buff/cache     
MiB Swap:   1024.0 total,   1024.0 free,      0.0 used.   2456.4 avail Mem      
 
  PID USER      PR  NI    VIRT    RES    SHR S  %CPU  %MEM     TIME+ COMMAND    
    1 root      20   0    3744   3064   2588 S   0.0   0.1   0:00.03 bash       
 2914 root      20   0    5736   2604   2216 R   0.0   0.1   0:00.00 top

Press q to exit top.

Send interrupt

We can simulate pressing CTRL-C to quit long-running processes:

$ sleep 1000
^C
$
